common: Lactation: not known if crosses in to breast milk, avoid
Lactation: not known if crosses in to breast milk, avoid
Hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperchloremic acidosis, cirrhosis, severe liver or renal impairment, adrenal gland failure
COPD, emphysema, concomitant high-dose aspirin or steroid therapy, or hepatic insufficiency
Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur

description.common: methazolamide will decrease the level or effect of amantadine by  Other (see comment). Modify Therapy/Monitor Closely. Excretion rate of amantadine increases rapidly when urine is acidic, administration of urine acidifying drugs may increase elimination of amantadine from the body. Monitor for efficacy of amantadine.

methazolamide, aspirin.
Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.

methazolamide, aspirin rectal.
Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.

Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.

dichlorphenamide and methazolamide both decrease  serum potassium. Use Caution/Monitor.

methazolamide, diflunisal.
Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.
methazolamide will increase the level or effect of lisdexamfetamine by  passive renal tubular reabsorption - basic urine. Use Caution/Monitor.

methazolamide, mesalamine.
Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.

methazolamide increases toxicity of metformin by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Decreases serum bicarbonate and induce non-anion gap, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

methazolamide, salicylates (non-asa).
Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.

Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.

Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.
tobramycin inhaled and methazolamide both increase  nephrotoxicity and/or ototoxicity. Modify Therapy/Monitor Closely. Avoid concurrent or sequential use to decrease risk for ototoxicity

topiramate, methazolamide.
Either increases toxicity of the other by pharmacodynamic synergism. Use Caution/Monitor. Increased risk of kidney stone formation.

methazolamide, willow bark.
Either increases levels of the other by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. 
Comment: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) and salicylates inhibit each other's renal tubular secretion, resulting in increased plasma levels.  CAIs also shift salicylates from plasma to the CNS, leading to potential neurotoxicity.
methazolamide, amobarbital. Mechanism: pharmacodynamic synergism. Minor/Significance Unknown. Increased risk of anticonvulsant induced osteomalacia.
methazolamide, butabarbital. Mechanism: pharmacodynamic synergism. Minor/Significance Unknown. Increased risk of anticonvulsant induced osteomalacia.
